moves.1. Nf3 d5 2. e3 b6 3. d4 Bb7 4. Bb5+: I'm not a fan of this move, as it allows Black to gain a tempo.
moves.4... c6 5. Ba4 Nf6 6. Bd2 e6 7. a3 Bd6 8: Even with the fianchetto, Black is as well developed as White.
moves.10. b4 a6 11. Re1 c5 12. Bxd7 Qxd7 13. e: A nice maneuver to regain the e4 pawn.
moves.14... cxb4: But this makes a bigger threat.
moves.16. Ncxe4 Qxd4: White regained the e4 pawn, but lost the pawn on d4.
moves.17. Nxf6+ gxf6: Qxf6 drops the B on b4.
moves.18. Bxb4 Qxb4: Black is now two pawns up and has the tempo, since White's N is attacked.
moves.19. Rb1 Qc5 20. Nxh7: This is a gamble that White can use the open files near the K to win or draw.
moves.20... Kxh7 21. Rxb6 Rab8: Qxb6 leads at best to a draw, due to Qh5+.
moves.22. Qd3+ Kg7 23. Qg3+ Qg5: Interposing here is not possible if the Q is on b6.  Now, White's Q is pinned due to the threat of Qxg2#.
moves.24. Rb3 Bd5 25. Rbe3 Rfh8 26. f3: f3 disconnects the Q and R.
moves.26... Qxg3 27. hxg3 Rhc8 28. c3: Now Black is up a clear piece.
moves.32. g4 Rg3 33. Rf2 Rxg2+: Time to take advantage of the passed pawn on a5.
moves.34. Rxg2 Bxg2 35. Kxg2 a4: White's K is out of the square and cannot stop the pawn.
